bioghist.p: Dorothy M. Spencer did field work in India from 1939-1942, 1946-1948, and for brief periods in 1951 and 1952, supported by the American Philosophical Society, the American Council of Learned Societies, and the Guggenheim Foundation.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists documentation related to Spencer's work in India. Materials include: manuscript and typed notes such as field notes, notes from interviews, results of psychological tests (Rorschach), transcriptions of police reports, and transcriptions of songs and poems; notes on various topics, including dreams, marriage ceremonies, economics, sacrifices, children's games, witchcraft, animals, and property; index cards to Spencer's Munda materials; records of the Government of India Anthropology Survey; an 8mm movie film labeled "Fiji"; reprints on tribes/Indian anthropology and articles on interpretation of Rorschach tests; and course materials such as student exams, papers, bibliographies, a grade sheet, and blank exam sheets.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
